title: Vectors

metadata.description: Learn about Vectors with clear explanations and practical examples.

Motion
Vectors are the building blocks of
Motion
In geometry, a vector can describe a movement from one point to another.
The vector [3, 2] says go 3 right and 2 up.
Vector Addition
The sum of two vectors (
a+b
) is found by moving the vector
b
until the tail meets the head of vector
a
.
(This does not change vector b).
Then, the line from the tail of
a
to the head of
b
is the vector
a+b
:

content_sections.title: Vector
content_sections.content:
-a
is the opposite of
+a
.
This means that vector a and vector -a has the same magnitude in opposite directions:
Scalar Operations
Vectors can be modified by adding, subtracting, or multiplying a scalar (number) from all the vector values:
a = [1 1 1]
a + 1 = [2 2 2]
[1 2 3] + 1 = [2 3 4]
Vector multiplications has much of the same properties as normal multiplication:
[2 2 2] * 3 = [6 6 6]
[6 6 6] / 3 = [2 2 2]
Force
Force
is a Vector.
Force is a vector with a
Magnitude
and a
Direction
.
Velocity
Velocity
is a Vector.
Velocity is a vector with a
Magnitude
and a
Direction
.

summary: This tutorial covers Vectors concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use Vectors effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of Vectors and how to apply it in your projects.
